titleStmt.title: Improved artificial bee colony algorithm for global optimization

analytic.title: Improved artificial bee colony algorithm for global optimization

biblStruct.note: Received 2 August 2010 Received in revised form 29 May 2011 Accepted 7 June 2011

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

textClass.keywords: Randomized algorithms Artificial bee colony algorithm Initial population Solution search equation Search mechanism

div.p: The artificial bee colony algorithm is a relatively new optimization technique. This paper presents an improved artificial bee colony (IABC) algorithm for global optimization. Inspired by differential evolution (DE) and introducing a parameter M, we propose two improved solution search equations, namely "ABC/best/1" and "ABC/rand/1". Then, in order to take advantage of them and avoid the shortages of them, we use a selective probability p to control the frequency of introducing "ABC/rand/1" and "ABC/best/1" and get a new search mechanism. In addition, to enhance the global convergence speed, when producing the initial population, both the chaotic systems and the opposition-based learning method are employed. Experiments are conducted on a suite of unimodal/multimodal benchmark functions. The results demonstrate the good performance of the IABC algorithm in solving complex numerical optimization problems when compared with thirteen recent algorithms.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Learning from life system, people have developed many optimization computation methods to solve complicated problems in recent decades, such as genetic algorithm (GA) inspired by the Darwinian law of survival of the fittest [1], particle swarm optimization (PSO) inspired by the social behavior of bird flocking or fish schooling [2], ant colony optimization (ACO) inspired by the foraging behavior of ant colonies [3], and biogeography-based optimization (BBO) inspired by the migration behavior of island species [4]. We call this kind of algorithms for scientific computation as "Artificial-Life Computation". Motivated by the specific intelligent behaviors of honey bee swarms, Karaboga in 2005 [5] proposed the artificial bee colony (ABC) algorithm to optimize multivariable and multimodal continuous functions. Numerical comparisons demonstrated that the performance of the ABC algorithm is competitive to other population-based algorithms with the advantage of employing fewer control parameters [6][7][8]. Due to its simplicity and ease of implementation, the ABC algorithm has captured much attention and has been applied to solve many practical optimization problems [9][10][11].

However, similar to other evolutionary algorithms, the standard ABC algorithm also faces up to some challenging problems. For example, the convergence speed of the ABC algorithm is typically slower than those of the representative population-based algorithms (e.g., differential evolution (DE) [12] and particle swarm optimization (PSO) [2]) when handling the unimodal problems, since it cannot utilize the information adequately to determine the most promising search direction. What is more, the ABC algorithm can also easily get trapped in the local optima when solving complex multimodal problems [8]. These weaknesses have restricted the wider applications of the ABC algorithm [10].

Therefore, accelerating convergence speed and avoiding the local optima have become two most important and appealing goals in the ABC research. A number of variant ABC algorithms have, hence, been proposed to achieve these goals. To mention a few, Tsai et al. [13] introduced the concept of universal gravitation into the consideration of the affection between the employed bees and the onlooker bees and proposed the interactive ABC optimization. Some researchers [14,15] took advantage of the information of the best solutions to improve the performance of the ABC 0020-0190/$ -see front matter © 2011 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved. doi:10.1016/j.ipl.2011.06.002 algorithm. D. Karaboga and B. Basturk [16] proposed a modified ABC algorithm by controlling the frequency of perturbation and introducing the ratio of the variance operator. Kang et al. [17] used the Rosenbrock's rotational direction method to implement the exploitation phase and proposed the Rosenbrock ABC algorithm. Alatas [18] introduced the chaotic maps into the initialization and chaotic search into the scout bee phase and proposed the chaotic ABC algorithm. However, so far, it seems to be difficult to simultaneously achieve both of the goals. For example, the chaotic ABC algorithm [18] focuses on avoiding the local optima, but brings in more extra function evaluations in chaotic search as a result.

To achieve both of the goals, inspired by DE and introducing a parameter M, we propose two improved solution search equations, namely "ABC/best/1" and "ABC/rand/1". Then, in order to take advantage of them and avoid the shortages of them, we use a selective probability p to control the frequency of introducing "ABC/rand/1" and "ABC/best/1" and get a new search mechanism. In addition, to enhance the global convergence speed, when producing the initial population, both the chaotic systems and the opposition-based learning method are employed. Based on these operations, the improved artificial bee colony algorithm for global optimization is proposed.

div.head: Standard artificial bee colony algorithm
div.p: This section outlines the standard ABC algorithm briefly which can be referred to [5]. The artificial bee colony consists of three groups of bees: employed bees, onlookers and scouts. Half of the colony consists of employed bees, and the other half includes onlooker bees. Employed bees search the food around the food source in their memory, meanwhile they pass their food information to onlooker bees. Onlooker bees tend to select good food sources from those found by the employed bees, and then further search the food around the selected food source. Scouts abandon their food sources and search new ones.

In the ABC algorithm, the position of a food source represents a possible solution to the optimization problem, and the nectar amount of a food source corresponds to the profitability (fitness) of the associated solution. Each food source is exploited by only one employed bee. In other words, the number of employed bees is equal to the number of food sources existing around the hive (number of solutions in the population). The employed bee whose food source has been abandoned becomes a scout.
An onlooker bee chooses a food source depending on the probability value P i associated with that food source,
div.formula: P i = fit i SN i=1 fit i , (1
div.p: where fit i is the fitness value of solution i; SN is the number of food sources which is equal to the number of employed bees or onlooker bees.
In order to produce a candidate food position
div.formula: V i = [v i,1 , v i,2 , . . . , v i,D ] from the old one X i = [x i,1 , x i,2 , . . . , x i,D
div.p: ] in memory, the ABC uses the following expression:
div.formula: v i, j = x i, j + Φ i, j (x i, j -x k, j ), (2
div.p: where k ∈ {1, 2, . . . , SN} and j ∈ {1, 2, . . . , D} are randomly chosen indexes; k is different from i; D is the number of variables (problem dimension); Φ i, j is a random number in the range -1, 1.

After each candidate source position is produced and evaluated by the artificial bee, its performance is compared with that of the old one. If the new food source has an equal or better quality than the old source, the old one is replaced by the new one. Otherwise, the old one is retained.

If a position cannot be improved further through a predetermined number of cycles, then that food source is assumed to be abandoned. The value of predetermined number of cycles is an important control parameter of the ABC algorithm, which is called limit for abandonment. Assume that the abandoned source is X i and j ∈ {1, 2, . . . , D}, then the scout discovers a new food source to replace X i . This operation can be defined as follows:
x i, j = x min, j + rand(0, 1)(x max, jx min, j ).

It should be noted that the components of the candidate food position V i may violate the predefined boundary constraints. Possible solutions to tackle this problem include resetting schemes, penalty schemes, etc. Constrained problems, however, are not the main focus of this paper. Thus, we follow a simple method [28] which sets the violating components to be the middle of the violated bounds and the corresponding components of the old one X i , i.e., v i, j = (x min, j + x i, j )/2, if v i, j < x min, j ; v i, j = (x max, j + x i, j )/2, if v i, j > x max, j .

div.head: Improved artificial bee colony algorithm
div.p: This section introduces the improved ABC algorithm in detail.

div.head: Initial population
div.p: Population initialization is a crucial task in evolutionary algorithms because it can affect the convergence speed and the quality of the final solution. If no information about the solution is available, then random initialization is the most commonly used method to generate initial population. Owing to the randomness and sensitivity dependence on the initial conditions of chaotic maps, the chaotic maps have been used to initialize the population so that the search space information can be extracted to increase the population diversity [18]. At the same time, according to [19], replacing the random initialization with the opposition-based population initialization can get better initial solutions and accelerate convergence speed. So this paper proposes a novel initialization approach which employs the chaotic systems and the opposition-based learning method to generate initial population. Here, logistic map is selected and its equation is defined as follows: where k is the iteration counter, K is the preset maximum number of chaotic iterations, μ is the control parameter.

In order to illustrate the randomness and sensitivity dependence on the initial conditions of Eq. (4), we present Figs. 1 and2, which show the distribution of the chaotic sequence. As is shown in Fig. 1, the chaotic sequence is relatively scattered, and almost traverses the whole interval [0, 1] when k gets big enough. In Fig. 2, '+' indicates the initial value of the sequence is set to 0.7. While '•' stands for the initial value of the sequence is set to 0.700001. It can be seen from Fig. 2 that even a small difference between the initial values (only 0.000001) can exert nonignorable influence on the sequence.

Based on these operations, we propose the following algorithm to generate initial population which can be used instead of a pure random initialization. Randomly initialize variables ch 0, j ∈ (0, 1); set iteration counter k = 0.
div.formula: While (k < K ) do ch k+1, j = μch k, j (1 -ch k, j ), 6: Set k = k + 1.
div.p: 7: End while. 8: OP i, j = x min, j + x max, j -P i, j , 17:
div.formula: P i, j = x min, j + ch k, j (x max, j -x min, j ),
div.p: Set j = j + 1.

End while 19: In order to further analyze the performance of the proposed initialization, we use 4 test functions to compare the basic ABC with the proposed initialization (ABC1 for short) and the basic ABC with the random initialization. The results are presented in Fig. 3. As can be seen in Fig. 3, the proposed initialization can improve the convergence speed.
div.formula: Set i = i + 1.

div.head: Two improved solution search equations
div.p: Differential evolution (DE) [12] has been shown to be a simple yet efficient evolutionary algorithm for many optimization problems in real-world applications. It follows the general procedure of an evolutionary algorithm. After initialization, DE enters a loop of evolutionary operations: mutation, crossover, and selection. There are several variant DE algorithms which are different in their different mutation strategies. Among them, the following mutation strategies are frequently used: "DE/best/1":
div.formula: V i = X best + F (X r1 -X r2 ),(5)
div.p: "DE/rand/1": (6) where i = {1, 2, . . . , SN}; r1, r2, and r3 are mutually different random integer indices selected from {1, 2, . . . , NP}; F is a positive real number, typically less than 1.0 that controls the rate at which the population evolves.
div.formula: V i = X r1 + F (X r2 -X r3 ),
div.p: Note that the best solutions in the current population are very useful sources that can be used to improve the convergence performance. The example is the "DE/best/1", where the best solutions explored in the history are used to direct the movement of the current population. At the same time, "DE/rand/1" can effectively maintain population diversity. Motivated by DE and based on the property of the ABC algorithm, we propose two new solution search equations as follows:
div.formula: v i, j = x best, j + Φ i, j (x i, j -x r1, j ), (7
v i, j = x r1, j + Φ i, j (x i, j -x r2, j ), (8
div.p: where the indices r1 and r2 are mutually exclusive integers randomly chosen from {1, 2, . . . , SN}, and both of them are different from the base index i; X best is the best individual vector with the best fitness in the current population and j ∈ {1, 2, . . . , D} is a randomly chosen index.

div.head: An efficient strategy
div.p: As can be seen from Eqs. ( 7)- (8), there is only one different element between the candidate source position and the old one, i.e., the jth element. Because the candidate source position is short of sufficient and new information, the search efficiency is poor. To address this problem, similar to [20,21], this paper proposes an efficient strategy by introducing a parameter M, which is used to control the number of the different elements between the candidate source position and the old one. Then Eqs. ( 7)-( 8) are changed to the following equations: "ABC/best/1": (10) where m = {1, 2, . . . , M}, and M is a positive integer, selected from {1, 2, . . . , D} that controls how many elements evolve.
div.formula: v i,m = x best,m + Φ i, j (x i,m -x r1,m ), (9) "ABC/rand/1": v i,m = x r1,m + Φ i, j (x i,m -x r2,m ),
div.p: Fig. 4 shows the search directions of the two search equations ( 9)- (10) in two dimensions. It can be seen that when M is 2, the improved search equations can search in the whole space. While the search equations ( 7)-( 8) can only search in the axes. Hence, the improved search equations can improve the search efficiency. Particularly, the more the value of the parameter M is, the more information is brought to the candidate source position. There is one point deserving to be paid attention to. In ABC algorithm a new solution is generated in the neighborhood of a current solution. Solution generated according to Eqs. (9) or (10) need not be necessarily in the neighborhood of current solution i. Moreover with higher value of M, the solution is generated more like the crossover operator of DE rather than the ABC algorithm. Nevertheless it doesn't mean that the search performance is improved all the time with the increase of M. How to choose the appropriate M will be analysed in Section 4.3.

div.head: The proposed search mechanism
div.p: Similar to DE, the solution search equation "ABC/best/1" which utilizes the information of the best solutions in the current population can improve the convergence performance but may lead to the premature convergence, especially when solving multimodal problems. While the solution search equation "ABC/rand/1" is known to be robust but less efficient in terms of the convergence speed. Hence, in order to take advantage of the compensatory property and avoid the shortages of them, we hybridize the two solution search equations and get a new search mechanism. Specifically, we use a selective probability p to control the frequency of introducing "ABC/rand/1" and "ABC/best/1". However, there is still one question concerning the proposed search mechanism, i.e., how to choose p in each cycle. This problem will be settled in Section 4.3.
div.formula: f 1 f 1 (X) = D i=1 x 2 i 30 Sphere (-100, 100) D f 2 f 2 (X) = D i=1 |x i | + D i=1 |x i | 30 Schwefel 2.22 (-10, 10) D f 3 f 3 (X) = D i=1 D j=1 x i 2 30 Schwefel 1.2 (-100, 100) D f 4 f 4 (X) = D i=1 x 2 j + D i=1 0.5ix i 2 + D i=1 0.5ix i 4 30 Zakharov (-5, 10) D f 5 f 5 (X) = D i=1 x i + 0.5 2 30
div.p: Step
div.formula: (-100, 100) D f 6 f 6 (X) = max i |x i |, 1 i D 30 Schwefel 2.21 (-100, 100) D f 7 f 7 (X) = D i=1 ix i + rand[0, 1) 30 Quartic (-128, 1.28)D f 8 f 8 (X) = D-1 i=1 100 x 2 i -x i+1 2 + x i -1 2 100 Rosenbrock (-30, 30) D f 9 f 9 (X) = - D i=1 sin(x i ) sin 20 i × x 2 i π 100 Michalewicz (0, π ) D f 10 f 10 (X) = - D i=1 x i sin |x i | 30 Schwefel (-500, 500) D f 11 f 11 (X) = D i=1
div.p: x 2 i -10 cos(2π x i ) + 10 30 Rastrigin (-5.12, 5.12)
div.formula: D f 12 f 12 (X) = D i=1 y 2 i -10 cos(2π y i ) + 10
div.p: where
div.formula: y i = x i |x i | < 0.5 round(2x i ) 2 |x i | 0.5 30
div.p: Noncontinuous Rastrigin (-5.12, 5.12) D f 13
div.formula: f 13 (X) = 1 n D i=1 x 4 i -16x 2 i + 5x i 100 Himmelblau (-5, 5) D f 14 f 14 (X) = 1 4000 D i=1 x 2 i - D i=1 cos x i √ i + 1 3 0 G r i e w a n k (-600, 600) D f 15 f 15 (X) = D i=1 kmax k=0 a k cos 2π b k (x i + 0.5) -D kmax k=0 a k cos 2π b k (x i + 0.5)
div.p: where a = 0.5, b = 3, k max = 20.
30 Weierstrass
(-50, 50) D Based on the above explanation, the pseudo-code of the proposed search mechanism (denoted as Algorithm 2) is given below:
div.formula: Φ i,w(m) = 1 -2 • rand, 6: v i,w(m) = x r1,w(m) + Φ i,w(m) (x i,w(m) -x r2,w(m) ),

div.p: Set m = m + 1.
End while 9: Else then 10:
div.formula: While (m < M) do 11: Φ i,w(m) = 1 -2 • rand, 12: v i,w(m) = x best,w(m) + Φ i,w(m) (x i,w(m) -x r1,w(m) ),

div.p: Set m = m + 1.
End while 15: End if

div.head: The improved artificial bee colony algorithm (IABC)
div.p: Having discussed all the components of the IABC algorithm, we present the complete computational procedure as follows:

Step0. Initialization: Preset parameter M, selective probability p, population size SN and limit. Step1. Perform Algorithm 1 to create an initial population, calculate the function values of the population. Step2. Produce new solutions V i for the employed bees by using Algorithm 2 and evaluate them. Apply the greedy selection process for the employed bees. Step3. Calculate the probability values P i for the solutions X i by (1). Produce the new solutions V i for the onlookers by using Algorithm 2 from the solutions X i selected depending on P i and evaluate them. Apply the greedy selection process for the onlookers.

Step4. Determine the abandoned solution for the scout, if exists, and replace it with a new randomly produced solution X i by (3). Step5. If the stopping criterion is satisfied, stop. Otherwise, return to Step 2.

div.head: Test function
div.p: In this section, the IABC algorithm is applied to minimize a set of 15 scalable benchmark functions of dimensions D = 30 and a set of 3 functions of higher dimension D = 100, as shown in Table 1. Specifically, functions f 1 -f 6 and f 8 are unimodal; function f 7 is a noisy quartic function; functions f 9 -f 18 are multimodal functions and the number of local minima increases exponentially with the problem dimension.

div.head: Experimental setup
div.p: In order to testify the efficiency of the proposed algorithm, the experiment results are compared with the standard DE, standard PSO, standard ABC, OEA, HPSO-TVAC, CLPSO, APSO, SaDE, jDE, JADE, CABC, GABC and RABC. The population size of IABC, DE, PSO and ABC is 50 (i.e., SN = 25), limit is SN * D, as used or recommended in [5][6][7][8], the selective probability p is 0.25 and the values of parameter M are listed in Table 1. For DE, PSO, ABC, the other parameter values are chosen as in [8]. Additionally, we follow the parameter settings in the original paper of OEA [22], HPSO-TVAC [23], CLPSO [24], APSO [25], SaDE [26], jDE [27], JADE [28], CABC [18], GABC [14] and RABC [17]. And the population for all the considered algorithms (except IABC) is initialized by the random initialization method. See Table 2.

div.head: Effects of the parameter M and selective probability p on the performance of IABC
div.p: In this section, we investigate the impact of the parameter M and selective probability p on the new algorithm. Note that Sphere, Schwefel 2.21, Rastrigin and Griewank in Table 1 are representative. Hence, in our experiments, the parameter M and selective probability p are tested according to the four situations. Specifically, the IABC algorithm runs 30 times on each of the functions, and the mean values of the final results are plotted in Figs. 5 and6. Here, when painting on the functions Rastrigin and Griewank, 5.0e-21 is used instead of 0 for convenience. As all the test functions are minimization problems, the smaller the final result, the better it is.

From Fig. 5, we can observe that M can influence the results. When M is 25, we obtain a faster convergence speed and better results on the Sphere function. For the other three test functions, better results are obtained when M is 10, 1 and 3 respectively. In particular, the performance of the IABC algorithm is most sensitive to M on the functions Rastrigin and Griewank.

From Fig. 6, we can observe that the selective probability p can also have effect on the results. When p is 0, we obtain a faster convergence speed and better results on the Sphere function. For the other three test functions, better results are obtained when p is around 0.25. Therefore, in our experiments, the selective probability p is set at 0.25 for all the test functions.

div.head: Results
div.p: In this section, we give the experiment results of the algorithms in Tables 3456. At the same time, we use t-distribution test which is quite popular among re-searchers in evolutionary computing [29] to compare the means of the results produced by the best and the second best algorithms (with respect to their final accuracies). In the last columns of Tables 3-6 we report the statistical significance level of the difference of the means of two best algorithms. Note that here '+' indicates the t value is significant at a 0.05 level of significance by two-tailed test, '•' means the difference of means is not statistically significant and 'NA' stands for Not Applicable, covering cases for which the two algorithms achieve the same accuracy results.

Firstly, we compare the IABC algorithm with DE, PSO and ABC with the same number of 5.0 × 10 4 function evaluations (FEs) for each test function. The results are shown in Table 3 in terms of the best, worst, mid, mean and st.d of the solutions obtained in the 30 independent runs by each algorithm. The best results are marked in bold. As is shown in Table 3, when solving the unimodal problems, the IABC algorithm offers the best performance on all the test functions. In particular, it offers the highest accuracy on functions f 1 and f 2 and improves the precision by one or four orders of magnitude on functions f 3 , f 4 , f 6 and f 7 , when compared with the best results of the other algorithms. The IABC algorithm can also find the optimal or closer-to-optimal solutions on the complex multimodal functions f 10 , f 11 , f 13 , f 14 , f 15 , f 16 , f 17 and f 18 . Although the results of high-dimension functions f 8 and f 9 are a little far from the global optimums, the IABC algorithm outperforms the other algorithms all the same. In Table 4, we compare IABC with OEA, HPSO-TVAC, CLPSO and APSO on 12 benchmark functions described in [25], where OEA uses the number of 3.0 × 10 5 FEs and the other algorithms use the number of 2.0 × 10 5 FEs. The results of OEA, HPSO-TVAC, CLPSO and APSO are gained from [23] and [25] directly. As can be seen from Table 4, IABC greatly outperforms OEA, HPSO-TVAC, CLPSO and APSO with better mean and standard deviation.

The further experiment results are listed in Table 5, which show the performance comparisons among SaDE, jDE, JADE and IABC on 13 benchmark functions chosen from [28]. The results of JADE, jDE and SaDE are gained from [28] directly. It can be seen from Table 5 that IABC performs much better than these DE variants on almost all the functions, while JADE performs much better than IABC on function Quartic.

At last, IABC is compared with CABC [18], GABC [14] and RABC [17]. The parameters of the algorithms are identical to [17]. The results, which have been summarized in Table 6, show that IABC performs much better in most cases than these ABC variants. Therefore, it can be concluded that IABC is more efficient than these ABCs.

The t-test results also clearly indicate that the difference between the IABC algorithm and the other algorithms is statistically significant in most cases. Therefore, it is evident that the IABC algorithm has a good performance. In a word, the IABC algorithm can improve bees' searching abilities, prevent bees from falling into the local minimum, increase convergence speed and compute more efficiently.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: In this paper, we have developed a novel algorithm, IABC, to solve global numerical optimization problems by introducing a new initialization approach and a novel search mechanism. We testify the performance of the proposed approach on a suite of unimodal/multimodal benchmark functions and provide comparisons with some other algorithms. The results show that the IABC algorithm possesses superior performance in accuracy, convergence speed, stability and robustness, as compared to the other algorithms. Hence, the IABC algorithm may be a good alternative to deal with complex numerical optimization problems.

However, the IABC algorithm has some shortages at the same time. From Tables 3, 4 and 5, compared to the other algorithms with the same function evaluations, the accuracy obtained by the IABC algorithm on function f 8 -Rosenbrock function is highest. However, the accuracy is still not satisfied. As can be seen in Fig. 7 that the function f 8 looks like a deep arced gorge. Since the bees easily go down to the bottom, it is hard for IABC to find the global optimum with less function evaluations. So ameliorating the algorithm inspired by the foraging behavior of honeybees for these special problems is our future work. Practical applications of the proposed approach in areas of clustering, data mining, design and optimization of communication networks, would also be worth studying.
